sub_title: PhD researcher, co-founder iMPACT DOC, documentary photographer
summary:
Having worked and lived extensively in various contexts in the Global South, Steyn began to develop a keen interest for documentary photography as a means to provoke a wider and more nuanced discussion around (mis)representation and foster dialogue and action around social and environmental injustices. Always rooted in social sciences research traditions, this is something he would refer to as visual- and research based activism, especially in conjunction with other media. 

He founded iMPACT JOURNEY as a platform and project agency, to support visual storytellers around the world. in 2017 he co-founded a non-profit space for documentary photography with his sister, iMPACT DOC. They hosted various masterclasses, documentary screenings and co-curated exhibitions in Amsterdam and in international partnerships. Core to most of their activities was the bringing together of academics, journalists and visual artists. Not only to learn, but also to co-create.

His work was recognised by several international media and institutions through awards, grants and publications.  He is always on the look-out for new and unexpected collaborations between disciplines and cross-overs between media. None of the 'visual projects' were commissioned, but rather self initiated and researched. 

Steyn was born in the Netherlands (1986), where he studied Cultural Anthropology, Development Sociology (BSc) at the Radboud University Nijmegen and Environmental Science (MSc) at the VU University Amsterdam. Currently he is working as a PhD researcher in Human Geography at Loughborough University in the UK, exploring just energy transitions in urban informal settlements. Ethnography, Participatory research and co-production of visual stories are at the core of his research and dissemination. He currently lives in Accra.

profile_positions.location: School of Social Sciences and Humanities. Geography and Environment.
profile_positions.description:
The number of people with access to modern energy services has increased significantly throughout the last decades. However, a recent report (ESMAP, 2020) shows that still 4 billion people lack access to affordable, reliable and clean energy services to meet their basic needs. Even though it varies widely within- and between countries, the situation is worse in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) where more than three quarters of the people remain dependent on biomass fuels, such as firewood, charcoal, dung and agricultural residues as their primary sources of household energy.

These contexts are more and more under pressure by processes of rapid urbanisation, contributing to the establishment of informal, unplanned settlements, often times characterized by a lack of adequate, reliable and basic municipal services, such as electricity, sanitation, water and waste disposal.

To meet a decent standard of living for all, this research explores how just energy (cooking) futures might look like in these peri-urban informal settlements. It attempts to provide an insight in the transition towards these futures informed by justice in a Ghanaian context.   The (participatory) process and outcome will be translated and presented in an innovative way to support a wide range of expert or non-expert actors.

This research has a strong resonance with ongoing research amongst the Low Carbon Energy for Development Network (LCEDN) as well as new interests in clean cooking through the Modern Energy Cooking Services (MECS) programme.
profile_positions.title: Doctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description:
Originating from iMPACT JOURNEY, iMPACT DOC is a non-profit institution for documentary photography and film in Amsterdam. Previous exhibition was Sarker Protick’s ‘Of River and Lost Lands’. A photographic essay of the river Padma (Ganges) in Bangladesh in times of climate change.

Stay updated for upcoming talks, workshops and other events.
profile_positions.title: Co-founder

profile_positions.description: iMPACT JOURNEY is a platform focusing on innovative ways of visual storytelling on global issues. It was founded on the urgency and necessity for a sustainable transition in order to combat (rising) inequality, climate change and to overcome the huge misunderstanding and misrepresentation of 'the other'.
profile_positions.title: Founder

company.name: Independent Sustainable Energy and Climate Research

profile_positions.company: Independent Sustainable Energy and Climate Research
profile_positions.description: Field Research stretching throughout the Global South, with a particular focus on (West)Africa, South (East)Asia. (Former) Clients and Partners: FairClimate Fund, Witteveen+Bos, Low Carbon Energy for Development Network, Loughborough University UK, Modern Energy Cooking Services Programme, GAMOS UK, VU University Amsterdam, Climate-KIC, Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs and a variety of local organisations.
profile_positions.title: Action Researcher // A Better Future Today

profile_positions.description: 6 ECTS Energy and Globalization as part of the Globalization: Key Debates and Issues Module (30 ECTS, MSc). This module introduces students to debates surrounding the concept of globalization and shows how this concept has been invoked in a variety of geographical scholarship on the nature of space, place and territory.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Lecturer Energy and Globalization (MSc)

profile_positions.description: Post-graduate programme for climate professionals. The programme involved a national placement with the Economic Board Utrecht focusing on the sustainable energy transition. And, from September to November, a placement at the Loughborough University and Low Carbon Energy Development Network (LCEDN) in the United Kingdom. Participation in Engineering for 'Social Change' at Royal Academy of Engineering in collab with UCL, University College London.
profile_positions.title: Pioneers into Practice Programme

profile_positions.description: MIT Award winning scale-up connecting a wide range of stakeholders to accelerate the sustainable energy transition. Support of neighbourhoods, (small-)business enterprises, industrials and (local) governments to gain ownership of their energy household. Thus creating energy cost into long-term value creation, away from fossil fuel dependence. Active both the Netherlands as well as introducing the concept in the Global South.
profile_positions.title: Franchise Partner, Partnership Broker

profile_positions.description: Co-responsibility for the internal and external publications, newsfeed and conferences geared towards lobby and advocacy work.
profile_positions.title: Communication Officer

profile_positions.description: Activities: conducting semi-structured and open interviews with relevant stakeholders, stakeholder analysis, collecting and analyzing documents, facilitating focus group discussions in rural areas, developing an impact measurement tool, in depth research on sugarcane production, comparison of biofuel certification schemes.
profile_positions.title: MSc Field Research on Sustainable Biofuel Feedstock Production

volunteer_experiences.description:
Platform for professionals, academics, students, practitioners and those interested in international development. HuCom strives for: (1) better communication about countries in the 'Global South' and; (2) an open, nuanced debate on development cooperation. 

www.humanitairecommunicatie.nl

Coordinator Dutch Delegation Youth and Green Programme Italy

volunteer_experiences.description: World Wide Opportunities on Organic Farms

Focussing on improving urban livelihoods through action research and implementation with(in) the Energy and Food Nexus. As of now active in Ghana, Accra. For our latest projects and support: www.lastsupperproject.org
